titles.title: FY2000 Budget Reconciliation Appropriations bill
Marriage Penalty Tax bill
Marriage Tax Relief Bill
Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000
Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000
To provide for reconciliation pursuant to section 103(a)(1) of the concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2001.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 545 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4810 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. Measure will be considered read. A specified amendment is in order. The amendment printed in H. Rept. 106-545 shall be in order without intervention of any point of order, shall be considered as read, and shall be separately debatable for one hour equally divided and controlled.
Rule H. Res. 545 passed House.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 545.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 4810 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. Measure will be considered read. A specified amendment is in order. The amendment printed in H. Rept. 106-545 shall be in order without intervention of any point of order, shall be considered as read, and shall be separately debatable for one hour equally divided and controlled.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H.R. 4810.
DEBATE - Pursuant to H. Res. 545, the House proceeded with one hour of debate on the Rangel amendment in the nature of a substitute.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
Mr. Rangel moved to recommit with instructions to Ways and Means.

Floor summary: DEBATE - The House proceeded with ten minutes of debate on the Rangel motion to recommit with instructions. The instructions contained in the motion require the bill to be reported back to the House forthwith with an amendment adding a new section which provides that the tax reductions contained in the bill are contingent on the enacting of Medicare Prescription Drug Benefits and no on-budget deficits.
The previous question on the motion to recommit with instructions was ordered without objection.
On motion to recommit with instructions Failed by recorded vote: 197 - 230 (Roll no. 391).

vote.text: On passage Passed by recorded vote: 269 - 159 (Roll no. 392).

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

calendar.text: Received in the Senate. Read twice. Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 677.

action.text: Measure laid before Senate.
Senate struck all after the Enacting Clause and substituted the language of S. 2839 amended. To be considered original text for the purpose of further amendments.
Point of order that the bill violates section 313 of the Budget Act raised in Senate.
Motion to waive the Budget Act with respect to the measure made in Senate.
Motion by Senator Feingold to commit to Senate Committee on Finance with instructions made in Senate.
Considered by Senate.
Motion by Senator Feingold to commit to Senate Committee on Finance rejected in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 45 - 49. Record Vote Number: 198.
Motion to waive the Budget Act with respect to the measure agreed to in Senate.
Considered by Senate.

vote.text: Passed Senate with an amendment by Yea-Nay Vote. 61 - 38. Record Vote Number: 215.

action.text: Senate insists on its amendment, asks for a conference, appoints conferees Roth, Lott and Moynihan.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Mr. Archer moved that the House disagree to the Senate amendment, and agree to a conference.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
On motion that the House disagree to the Senate amendment, and agree to a conference Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Cardin moved that the House instruct conferees.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the motion to instruct conferees. The instructions contained in the motion instructs the managers on the part of the House, to the maximum extent permitted within the scope of the conference to (1) maximize the amount of marriage penalty relief provided to middle and low income taxpayers; (2) minimize the additional marriage bonuses provided to taxpayers already receiving marriage bonuses under current law; and (3) resolve the differences in effective dates and phase-in amounts in a way which takes into account fiscal responsibility.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
On motion that the House instruct conferees Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 203 - 222 (Roll no. 408).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
The Speaker appointed conferees: Archer, Armey, and Rangel.
Conferees agreed to file conference report.
Conference report H. Rept. 106-765 filed.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 559 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of the conference report to H.R. 4810. All points of order against the conference report and against its consideration are waived. The conference report shall be considered as read. H. Res. 556 is laid on the table.
Conference papers: Senate report and manager's statement held at the desk in Senate.
Rule H. Res. 559 passed House.
Mr. Archer brought up conference report H. Rept. 106-765 for consideration under the provisions of H. Res. 559.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the Conference Report on H.R. 4810.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
Motions to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

vote.text: On agreeing to the conference report Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 271 - 156 (Roll no. 418).

action.text: Conference papers: message on House action held at the desk in Senate.
Conference report considered in Senate.
Conference report considered in Senate.

vote.text: Senate agreed to conference report by Yea-Nay Vote. 60 - 34. Record Vote Number: 226.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Vetoed by President.
The Chair laid before the House the veto message from the President.
Mr. Archer moved to refer the bill and accompanying veto message to the Committee on Ways and Means.
On motion to refer the bill and the accompanying veto message to the Committee on Ways and Means. Agreed to without objection.
Mr. Archer moved to discharge the Committee on Ways and Means from further consideration of the veto message from the President.
On motion to discharge the Committee on Ways and Means from further consideration of the veto message from the President. Agreed to without objection.
Committee discharged.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the veto override on H.R. 4810.

vote.text: On passage, the objections of the President to the contrary notwithstanding Failed by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 270 - 158 (Roll no. 466).

action.text: Motion to refer the bill and accompanying veto message to the Committee on Ways and Means.
On motion to refer the bill and the accompanying veto message to the Committee on Ways and Means. Agreed to without objection.

bill.summary: 7/19/2000--Conference report filed in House. Marriage Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2000 - States that no amendment made by this Act shall be treated as a tax rate change for purposes of section 15 (effect of changes on tax rates) of the Internal Revenue Code.(Sec. 2) Amends the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) to provide that the basic standard deduction for a married couple filing jointly shall be twice the basic standard deduction for an unmarried individual, beginning in 2000.(Sec. 3) Provides that the 15 percent regular income tax bracket for a married couple filing jointly shall be twice the size of the corresponding bracket for an unmarried individual. Sets forth a graduated phase-in beginning in 2000 and fully effective in 2004.(Sec. 4) Increases the beginning point of the phase-out range of the earned income credit for married couples filing jointly by $2,000, beginning in 2000.(Sec. 5) Revises provisions concerning the allowance of nonrefundable personal tax credits to provide that the aggregate amount of such credits shall not exceed the sum of: (1) the taxpayer's regular tax liability for the taxable year reduced by the foreign tax credit; and (2) the alternative minimum tax.(Sec. 6) States that the amendments made by this Act shall not be taken into account under IRC provisions relating to failure to pay estimated tax in determining the amount of any installment required to be paid before October 1, 2000.(Sec. 7) Sets forth "Budget Act" compliance provisions (sunset provisions).
